content:
For some reasons (avoiding bias), the natural rule for breaking ties when rounding is to keep the even integer.

Therefore, I think that the text in the first paragraph should be changed (I don't care about the rounding mode in use for this puzzle, but I disturb me when the financial rounding mode is considered the normal way).


edit: Any rounding mode will lead to the correct answer.

Fast validation, without comment, nice

I have an issue about your puzzle :

"distance rounded to integer" : 
I think you must precise 'nearest' or 'lowest' integer for the rounding. (or another one if you want to use exotic rounding ;-) )

You should probably swap the order of the inputs.

Being obliged to store all the geolocations because we do not have the capitals yet is just painful. :(
For the orthodromic distance, please refer to https://www.codingame.com//training/easy/defibrillators .

:-(  Too bad, that I completely forgot about this puzzle although I solved it 4 months and 150 puzzles ago, not much later after I signed up for CG. I searched only for 'geolocation'  tag but found none. Now, there is way too much overlap. I am devastated :-((

I was about to modify it as you suggested, but now I see the puzzle is accepted and went live, so I don't dare to modify it anymore. By the way, although it is flattering having my puzzle accepted in less than 12 hours, but it would be better for CG to always leave at least 48 hours for suggestions, checks, etc even if 3 accept vote is already achieved.
Thanks for the feedback! I updated the statement. (I intended 'normal' rounding rules and not floor. Distance is always non-negative, so that is one less disambiguity.)

I updated the statement to clarify.
It is a nice example of 'cultural bias'. In Hungary I learned in math class the ''half round away from zero' as the 'normal' way to do rounding, so I automatically used that. Also, in PHP - which I used for sample solution - the built in round() uses PHP_ROUND_HALF_UP by default, which is the  same at least for positive distances.
So it is a nice example for that in international environment we shall not assume anything as 'normal way'.

I have removed the "edit" part, which will make absolutely no sense for newcomers.

I also thing that the disclaimer part should be moved here (in order to shorten the statement).

So far, 18 people solved it and success rate is 46%. So the edit part was only for the other 21 people who already started and might (or might not) want to continue and will be annoyed if does not know what happened.
At least half of them really don't care. And I do not know for the other half. ;)

Your puzzle was accepted without any of the three people validating it having said even a word.
In such a situation (great quality reviewing!), you should probably keep modifying and improving after acceptance when some people make the effort to actually review your puzzle.

Once again <insert here Niako's message>.

That being "said", I really think that we should focus on improving existing puzzles rather than creating new ones. Unfortunately, only the work on new puzzles is rewarded with XP. :(

Okay, I agree, but changing the order of input would break the codes of the few people who already solved it, plus also some people who started to solve it right now. I am not sure if I shall do this, if we talk only about a more natural order of input and not puzzle-breaking issues. But you are the CG veterans, so I shall do as suggested.
Broken code is a minor issue actually. People who solved your puzzle will still have 100%.

Order of input now changed. 
By the way, thanks for the review and feedback.
Thanks Zorg1 for noticing (on #Fr) that the formula in use in defibrilators is an approximation that is reasonable there, but not for your puzzle.
